The Co3O4 catalyst derived from ZIF-67 and their catalytic performance of toluene Kai Chen Writing - original draft Shuli Bai Conceptualization Resources * Huanying Li Investigation * Yaojia Xue Validation Xiaoyu Zhang Formal analysis Minchao Liu Supervision Jianbo Jia Data curation School of Biotechnology and Health Sciences, Wuyi University, Jiangmen 529020, China School of Biotechnology and Health Sciences Wuyi University Jiangmen 529020 China School of Biotechnology and Health Sciences, Wuyi University, Jiangmen 529020, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The reduction behaviour of Co3O4 by H2-TPR. A serial of Co3O4 catalysts were prepared through a facile method of calcining of ZIF-67 at different temperatures. Physicochemical properties of the samples were characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis-differential thermal analysis(TGA-DTA), scanning electron microscopy(SEM), the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller(BET) equation, H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques, and their catalytic performance were investigated for the oxidation of toluene. The structural characterization certified that the calcination temperature has an important effect to catalytic activities. With the increase of the calcination temperature, the BET surface area reduces, pore size increases and the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ and Oads/Olatt firstly increase then decrease. The results showed that the conversion of toluene on the Co3O4-400 catalyst could reach 100 % when the reaction temperature was 240 ºC. The Co3O4-400 catalyst presented better performance and excellent resistance to H2O, which are very important to Industrial application. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Cobalt tetroxide Toluene Catalytic oxidation 1 Introduction The problem of air pollution has gradually attracted the attention of the public. Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) as major atmospheric pollutants, which can cause the formation of photochemical smog and acid rain, seriously threaten the environmental safety and human health. The management of VOCs is facing serious challenges [1–4]. Among all of these VOCs treatment technologies, catalytic oxidation technology has become the most promising solution due to its low temperature, high efficiency and no secondary pollutants [5]. Therefore, the development of highly efficient, low-temperature and low-cost catalysts for VOCs degradation is a key factor. Supported noble metal catalysts (Pt [6,7], Pd [8], Au [9], etc.) have been proved to have excellent performance for the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. However, the high costs and easy poisoning of noble metal catalysts restrict the large-scale industrial applications [10]. Metal oxide catalysts (MnOx [11,12], Co3O4 [13,14], CeO2 [15], CuO [16], etc.) are considered to be effective substitutes for noble metal catalysts, and Co3O4 with spinel structure is widely used in catalytic fields because of its low-cost efficiency, relatively high catalytic performance and no secondary pollution [17–19]. Lv et al. [20]. reported the preparation of two morphologies of Co3O4 catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of CO, and found that Co3O4 nanotubes showed a much higher catalytic activity and stability than the spherical nanoparticles, which could be attributed to the tubular structure having better redox nature. Ma et al. [19]. synthesized Co3O4 catalyst with different morphologies (double-sided nanobrush, rods, hexagonal plates and double-side helianthus discs) by hydrothermal method for catalytic oxidation of benzene. They concluded that double-sided nanobrush Co3O4 catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity, which might be associated with the rich Co3+ species on the surface of the Co3O4 nanobrush catalyst, good low-temperature reducibility, a large number of lattice oxygen defects and high active oxygen species concentration. Ren et al. [21] synthesized a series of cobalt trioxide with different morphologies by template-free hydrothermal method and used in the catalytic oxidation of toluene, they concluded that 3D-Co3O4 nanoflower catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity. Meanwhile, larger surface area and highly defective structure can rise to more surface adsorbed oxygen species [22]. In addition, Co-based catalysts supported on various supports have received considerable attention in recent years [23,24]. The previous experimental results [25,26] revealed the supported catalyst had better catalytic conversation than the unsupported one, which suggested the support was a beneficial effect in the improvement of the catalytic performance. In recent years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) materials have proven to be an ideal sacrifice template for the preparation of porous metal oxides, and these metal oxides generally have a more dispersed active center and larger specific surface area and exhibits stronger physical and chemical properties [27]. For example, the spherical mesoporous MnOx nanoparticles were prepared using MOF-74 as a sacrifice template by changing the thermal decomposition conditions [28]. Zhou et al. [29] reported that CuO/Cu2O heterostructure was prepared via a Cu-MOF, and this catalyst displayed superior low-temperature NOx activity and N2 selectivity. Ce-BTC was used as a precursor to synthesize a mesoporous CeO2 for toluene combustion [30]. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks(ZIFs), as a class of MOFs, are formed in zeolite topologies from tetrahedral metal ions (e.g. Co, Cd, Zn) and imidazolate ligands, Co base ZIF-67 has been especially favored by many researchers [31–34]. Li and co-workers [35] synthesized ZIF-67 derived Co3O4 honeycomb-like structures only through a simple one-step calcination process for electrochemical water splitting. Li et al. [36] prepared a porous hollow structure Co3O4 polyhedron by direct pyrolysis of ZIF- 67 crystal in air, and showed better activity to CO oxidation activity. Meanwhile, it was discovered that the primary Co3O4 nanoparticles and pore diameters increase with increasing calcination temperatures. All these efforts have simultaneously demonstrated that MOFs derived metal oxides can not only keep the primary features of MOFs, such as high specific surface area and controllable porosity [37–40], but also the metal oxide catalysts with different appearance and pore size can be prepared by changing the synthesis conditions and pyrolysis temperature [39]. To our knowledge, controllable synthesis of Co3O4 catalyst using ZIF-67 as a sacrificial template for toluene oxidation is mainly by controlling the template synthesis method. Zhao et al. [41] synthesized different sizes(400 and 800 nm, 1.7 μm) hollow Co3O4 polyhedron by the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 and used in the catalytic oxidation of toluene, they concluded that the Co3O4-400 exhibited excellent catalytic activity, which might be associated with abundant surface oxygen, higher Co3+/Co2+ atomic ratio on the catalyst surface and the strongest feature peaks of the CoO and OH groups. However, the preparation of Co3O4 catalysts by changing the calcination temperature from zif-67 as a sacrificial template has not been reported. In this study, a series of Co3O4 catalysts were synthesized by self-pyrolysis of ZIF-67 by controlling calcination temperature. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of the as-prepared Co3O4 was evaluated for the toluene oxidation reaction. The structures and catalytic activities of as-prepared Co3O4 with different calcination temperature were further investigated with the help of TGA & DTA, SEM, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, and N2 adsorption-desorption characterizations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials synthesis In a typical synthesis of ZIF-67, 0.04 mol of 2-methylimidazole (aladdin, 98 %) was dissolved in 40 mL pure water and 0.01 mol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (aladdin, 99 %, AR) was dissolved in 40 mL of pure water. The cobalt salt quickly poured into the 2-methylimidazole solution under magnetic stirring, and then the mixture was continually stirred for 2 h at room temperature. The obtained solution was then filtered and washed several times with pure water and absolute ethanol, and then the product was dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. The as-prepared ZIF-67 precursors was placed in a muffle furnace heated to 300 °C at heating rate of 15 °C·min-1, and maintained at 300 °C for 4 h in the air, then naturally cooled to room temperature to finally obtain a black powder. The product was marked as Co3O4-300. Under the same conditions, calcination experiments were carried out at different temperatures of 350, 400, 450 and 500 °C, and the products obtained were labeled as Co3O4-350, Co3O4-400, Co3O4-450 and Co3O4-500, respectively. 2.2 Catalytic evaluation The test of catalytic activity was carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (i.d. = 8 mm). The dosage of catalyst was 100 mg. The toluene bubbling bottle was placed in a thermostatic bath, and a stream of oxygen was introduced into the bubbling bottle to bring out gaseous toluene. The reactant feed consisted of 1000-2000 ppm toluene, 14.9 % (vol) of O2 and N2 balance gas with a total gas flow of 100 ml/min. Use of gas-phase chromatographs equipped with FID detectors to determine the concentration of toluene exported. The toluene conversion ( X toluene ) rate was calculated by the following equation: X toluene = C i n − C o u t C i n × 100 % C i n was the concentration of toluene for entering the reaction tube; C o u t was the concentration of toluene at the outlet. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The composition of the as-prepared samples was determined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) with a Cu Kα (40 kV, 40 mA) radiation. The thermal stability of ZIF-67 under air was assessed using a TGA5500 (TA Instruments; America) thermogravimetric analysis (TGA & DTA) in the temperature range of 20-790 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C·min-1. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were measured using nitrogen adsorption and desorption of N2 at 77 K on 3Flex Physisorption (Micromeritics; America). The morphology of products were observed by S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi; Japan).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using K-Alpha (Thermo Scientific; America) XPS system from a monochromatic aluminum anode X-ray source with Kα radiation (1486.6 eV), and the spectra were calibrated with the C1s peak at 284.6 eV as an internal standard. Temperature Programmed Reduction in H2 (H2-TPR) was performance on a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics AutoChem II2920) under 10 vol. % H2 flow diluted with Ar gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of template The XRD pattern of the as-prepared ZIF-67 are shown in Fig. 1 (a). The diffraction peaks of the as-prepared ZIF-67 appears at 2θ of 7.4°, 10.4°, 12.7°, 14.8°, 16.5°, 18.0°, 22.1°, 24.5°, 26.7° and 29.5°, which is correspond to the (011), (002), (112), (022), (013), (222), (114), (233), (134) and (044) plants [33], respectively. In order to determine how the framework of ZIF-67 changes at different pyrolysis temperatures, the TGA curve of ZIF-67 was carried in the air. The TGA curve in Fig. 1(b) of ZIF-67 exhibits three stages, the first stages of about 3.1 % weight loss in the decomposition process 20–110 °C, which represents the water and ethanol move out of the channel; the second stages of about 23.4 % weight loss in the decomposition process from 110–322 °C, which represents the uncoordinated 2-methylimidazole molecule adsorbed in the MOF channel. There was a significant weight loss (45.0 %) in the decomposition process 322–367 °C, which can be mainly attributed to the collapse of the coordination bond between the metal and the ligand, causing the collapse of the framework and the decomposition of the organic ligands. There was no more weight loss at temperature above 367 °C due to the formation of stable Co3O4. 3.2 XRD analysis of catalysts The wide-angle XRD spectrum of the prepared sample is shown in Fig. 2 . It can be clearly seen that the as-prepared Co3O4-350, Co3O4-400, Co3O4-450 and Co3O4-500 displayed similar diffraction peaks, which match well to the cubic spinel Co3O4 (JCPDS card no.42-1467, space group Fd3m). There are several major diffraction peaks at 2θ of 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.8°, 38.5°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.4° and 65.2°, which can be ascribed to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440) plains, respectively [42]. It is worth noting that no peaks from other phase or impurity are observed in patterns of Co3O4 samples, indicating that the sacrifice template at 350–500 °C for 4 h was appropriate in generation of single-phase Co3O4. However, for the Co3O4-300 catalyst, although the weaker peak of Co3O4 can be observed, there is a sharp diffraction peak at 2θ of 14.1° for C(C70: JCPDS card no.48-1206). 3.3 Morphology The morphology of ZIF-67 template and prepared sample is shown in Fig. 3 . Three-dimensional structures can be observed for all materials. The as-prepared ZIF-67 template has a regular diamond structure. From the SEM characterization chart, the surface roughness of the Co3O4 catalyst obtained by calcination in air can be observed without maintaining the morphology of the template. The surface of Co3O4-300 catalyst obtained at 300 °C is distributed with relatively uniform Co3O4 particles. With the increase of temperature, the catalyst exhibits a three-dimensional flocculent structure with channel, and a clear honeycomb structure can be observed on the surface of Co3O4-400 catalyst. 3.4 Surface area and Surface chemical state analysis The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of Co3O4-x catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 (a) and (b), respectively. The specific surface areas of Co3O4-x catalysts are calculated by the BET method, pore volume, pore diameter and crystallite size by Scherer equation are presented in Table 1 . According to the IUPAC, all N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of samples exhibited type IV isotherm, and the hysteresis loops can be observed in the p/p 0 range at 0.4-1.0, 0.6-1.0, 0.6-1.0, 0.8-1.0 and 0.6-1.0 for Co3O4-300, Co3O4-350, Co3O4-400, Co3O4-450 and Co3O4-500, respectively, indicating that all samples have similar mesoporous structure [43,44]. Additionally, their average pore sizes are 11.48, 16.75, 17.25, 30.76 and 33.28 nm, and the corresponding specific BET surface area is 65.49, 51.11, 29.26, 11.51 and 1.76 m2 g-1. The results demonstrate the BET surface area reduces and pore size increases with the calcination temperature increase, which is also consistent with the XRD results. In order to further obtain information on the surface element compositions, chemical states and adsorbed/lattice oxygen species, all of Co3O4 catalysts was characterized by XPS. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), XPS spectra of Co 2p for all samples show two broad and asymmetric peaks at about 779∼782ev and 794∼798ev, which were corresponded to Co 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively, this results is consistent with previous work [36–39]. Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 can be devolution to two spin orbit doublets: octahedral Co3+(low energy) and tetrahedral Co2+(high energy), the fitting peaks of Co3O4-300 at the binding energy of 780.1 and 796.1 eV, Co3O4-350 at 781.2 and 796.3 eV, Co3O4-400 at 781.0 and 795.7 eV, Co3O4-450 at 781.2 and 796.4 eV, Co3O4-500 at 781.1 and 797.4 eV were corresponded to Co2+, while another fitting peaks of Co3O4-300 at 779.6 and 794.5 eV, Co3O4-350 at 779.7and 794.8 eV, Co3O4-400 at 779.4 and 794.5 eV, Co3O4-450 at 779.8 and 795.1 eV, Co3O4-500 at 779.7 and 795.1 eV were attributed to Co3+. The energy separation between the peak 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 splitting is approximately 15.1 eV, which indicated the presence of a mixture of Co2+ and Co3+ [27,45]. It should be noted that a low intensity shake-up satellite peak at about 787.7 eV was detected in the spectra, which suggest the presence of the Co3O4 phase [46]. Simultaneously, Co3+/Co2+ ratios were also listed in Table 2 . For five catalysts, the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ were 0.45, 0.452, 0.502, 0.459, and 0.482, respectively. O1s XPS spectra of samples are shown in Fig. 5(b), which can be divided into two peaks at binding energies of 531.0 ev and 529.9 ev [47,48]. That can be ascribed to adsorption oxygen (Oabs) and lattice oxygen (Olatt), respectively. Among them, Oabs was activated oxygen species derived from oxygen defects with lower coordination trait, which are active for toluene oxidation at low temperature [49].The ratio of Oads/Olatt are presented in Table 2 and it can be ranked as the decreasing order: Co3O4-400 > Co3O4-350 > Co3O4-300 > Co3O4-450=Co3O4-500. It was reported that the higher ratio of Oads/Olatt implied the higher concentration of vacant oxygen [50,51]. Especially, Co3O4-400 exhibits highest Oads/Olatt ratio (about 1.61), indicating it possesses the highest concentrations of surface-adsorbed oxygen than the others. It can be concluded that calcination temperature play an important role on influence of Co3+ relative content and surface adsorbed oxygen states. 3.5 Redox behavior of catalysts H2-TPR experiments were performed over catalysts prepared with different calcination temperature to investigate their reduction behavior and the profiles are shown in Fig. 6 . In general, the H2-TPR profiles of Co3O4 show two distinct peaks, the peaks at higher temperature is ascribed to Co2+ → Co°, and the peak at lower temperature belongs to Co3+ → Co2+ [52,53]. However, three reduction peaks were observed when the calcination temperature was 300℃, which is similar to results of Zhao et al. [54] and Huang et al. [55]. The first peak at 332℃ is corresponding to the reduction of Co3+→ Co2+, the broader peak in 400℃∼500℃ is attributed to the reduction of Co2+ → Co°. More specifically, the second peak can be ascribed to the reduction of Co2+ → Co° in the surface of Co3O4 nanoparticles, and the third can be in the bulk of Co3O4 nanoparticles. The other four catalysts show two peaks, the sharp peak at lower temperature belong to the reduction of Co3+→ Co2+, the broad peak at high temperature are ascribed to Co2+ → Co°, and the reduction peak shift to high temperature with increasing the calcination temperature, which is in consistent with literature report that the temperature shows a tendency to shift to high temperature as the particle size increases [56]. It is well known that the position of reduction peaks directly reflects the reduction properties of catalysts. This result indicated that the oxidizing ability of Co3O4-350 is stronger at low temperature. It's worth mentioning that a broader reduction peak spanning from 314 to 386℃is observed for Co3O4-400 catalyst, which could describe several overlapping reduction processes [57–60]. All these results indicate that Co2+ and Co3+ coexist on the catalyst surface, which is consistent with XPS results. Meanwhile, the areas of the second peak are obviously bigger than the first, which suggests that there are lots of Co2+ species on the surface of catalyst. The reduction property of catalyst is not only related to the crystalline size but also to the concentration of Co2+ on the surface of catalyst [61]. 3.6 Catalytic performance and stability The catalytic performances of Co3O4-x (x represent calcination temperature) catalysts are investigated and using catalytic toluene oxidation as model reaction. Fig. 7 (a) displays the conversation of toluene over catalysts under conditions of toluene concentration =1000 ppm and Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) =60000 h-1 at 240 °C. As shown in Fig. 7(a), before reaching 20 %, the conversion rate of toluene rose steadily and slowly over Co3O4-400, Co3O4-350 and Co3O4-300, and then suddenly reached around 100 % at 240 °C. For the Co3O4-450 catalyst, the 90 % conversion of toluene was up to 260 °C, while the Co3O4-500 catalyst keeps about 15 % conversation within the experimental temperature range. Compared to other catalysts, Co3O4-350 displays relative high activity when the experimental temperature was 200 °C, which could result from its lower reduction temperature. From the beginning of 210℃, the conversation ratio of toluene over Co3O4-400 exhibits higher performance than others, which probably results from its high ratio to Co3+/Co2+ and Oads/Olatt. According to Fig. 7(a), it can be seen that the reaction temperatures at the toluene conversion of 50 % (T50) and 90 % (T90) are listed in Table 3 . It is obvious that the catalytic performances of Co3O4-350, Co3O4-400 and Co3O4-300 is higher than those of Co3O4-450 and Co3O4-500. As seen from Table 3, the catalytic efficiencies of Co3O4-350, Co3O4-400 and Co3O4-300 were very close, and Co3O4-400 showed a little better performance at low temperatures. The results suggest that the continuous increase of calcination temperature would not simultaneously enhance the catalytic performance of toluene. Based on the temperature at 100 % conversation of reactant gas, a comprehensive comparison of Co3O4-400 catalytic performance in this work with other catalysts reported in the literature has been made. As seen in Table 4 , the catalytic performance of catalyst in this work is better than other catalysts, so the Co3O4-400 catalyst was selected for subsequent experiments because of its excellent performance. Fig. 7(b) displays the effect of toluene concentrations on the catalytic performance of the Co3O4-400. The conversion can reach about 100 % at 240 °C when the initial concentration of toluene was 1000 ppm. However, with the increase of initial concentration of toluene, the conversion of toluene decreased. In order to study the effect of GHSV on activity, we tested over Co3O4-400 catalyst for toluene oxidation, and the result was showed in Fig. 7(c). Obviously, the conversion of toluene decreased with the increasing the space velocity during the reaction temperature below 240 °C, but the change range was small. However, the conversation of toluene has no obviously change at 240 °C. It can be concluded the Co3O4-400 catalyst can exhibit better catalytic performance at 240 °C in the relatively larger GHSV range (60000-120000 h-1). Generally, the industrial activities VOCs emission contains water vapor, and it is prohibitive, so it is necessary to evaluated the effects of water vapor on the catalyst activity. Fig. 8 (a) showed the long-term stability test without water vapor over Co3O4-400 catalyst at 240℃ under the condition of GHSV=60000 h-1, no significant decrease has been observed during run of 80 h and the conversion of toluene remained above 99 %, which indicated the deactivation is negligible without the presence of water vapor. As a comparison, 5 vol % water vapor was introduced after the oxidation reaction was stabilized for 5 h, and the water vapor was cut off in three 3 h, then the conversion of toluene was tested for 12 h. As shown in Fig. 8(b), the conversion of toluene fluctuated over Co3O4-400 catalyst after the water vapor was cut off, but the conversion remained above 90 % in the test for 12 h. The result indicates that water vapor is adsorbed by the catalyst and occupies the activity sites of the catalyst, which will inhibit the activity of the catalyst to a certain extent [65]. The fluctuation may be attributed to the competitive adsorption of water and toluene as well as oxygen molecules for surface active sites [66]. To sum up, the catalyst shows some resistance to the water vapor and maintains excellent catalytic activity to a certain extent, which is crucial for practical application. 3.7 Oxidation reaction process It is well known that the catalytic oxidation performances of a transition-metal oxide on VOCs are affected by many factors, such as specific surface area, structural characteristics, surface ion valence and reactive oxygen and structure defects of catalyst [54,63]. For catalytic oxidation of VOCs, the catalysts with higher specific surface area are beneficial for exhibiting high catalytic activity [5,67]. The honeycomb structure on the surface of the catalyst facilitates the adsorption of oxygen and toluene molecules. The presence of reactive oxygen species promotes oxidation of toluene at lower temperatures. The conversion of toluene over the Co3O4-400 catalyst might contain the following processes: toluene reacts with the oxygen adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, and the partially reduced metal ions are activated by the gas phase oxygen to oxidize the metal ions, and the gas phase oxygen is converted into adsorbed oxygen to maintain the oxidation reaction. In the above process, oxygen transfer and Coδ+ conversion are important processes, and the process is as follows: O2(gas) ⇔ O2(ads) ⇔ O2 — (ads) ⇔ 2O— (ads) and Co3+ ⇔ Co2+ [33,68]. 4 Conclusion The Co3O4-x catalysts derived from ZIF-67 have been prepared by controlling calcination temperatures in the present work, and are used for the reaction of catalytic oxidation of toluene. The calcination temperature not only affects the morphology, porosity structure, specific surface area and crystallization, but also has a profound influence on the oxidation and reduction state on the surface of catalyst. It is found that the Co3O4-400 catalysts with honeycomb structure exhibited preferable performance (100 % toluene conversion at 240 °C), stability (remained above 99 % after 80 h of on-stream reaction) and good resistance to water vapor. coredata.dc:description: A serial of Co3O4 catalysts were prepared through a facile method of calcining of ZIF-67 at different temperatures. Physicochemical properties of the samples were characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis-differential thermal analysis(TGA-DTA), scanning electron microscopy(SEM), the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller(BET) equation, H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques, and their catalytic performance were investigated for the oxidation of toluene. The structural characterization certified that the calcination temperature has an important effect to catalytic activities. With the increase of the calcination temperature, the BET surface area reduces, pore size increases and the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ and Oads/Olatt firstly increase then decrease. The results showed that the conversion of toluene on the Co3O4-400 catalyst could reach 100 % when the reaction temperature was 240 ºC. The Co3O4-400 catalyst presented better performance and excellent resistance to H2O, which are very important to Industrial application.
coredata.dc:title: The Co3O4 catalyst derived from ZIF-67 and their catalytic performance of toluene
